requirements.text: Sijoitusrahastojen etuja mahdollisesti vahingoittavien eturistiriitojen määrittämiseksi rahastoyhtiön on kiinnitettävä huomiota erityisesti tilanteisiin, joissa rahastoyhtiö, vaikuttavassa asemassa oleva henkilö, tai määräysvallan kautta suoraan tai välillisesti rahastoyhtiöön sidoksissa oleva henkilö: voi saada taloudellista etua tai välttää taloudellisen tappion sijoitusrahaston kustannuksella; saa sijoitusrahastolle tai muulle asiakkaalle tarjotun palvelun tai suoritetun toiminnan taikka sijoitusrahaston tai muun asiakkaan lukuun toteutetun liiketoimen tulokseen liittyvää, sijoitusrahaston edusta poikkeavaa etua; saa taloudellista tai muunlaista kannustinta suosia sijoitusrahaston etujen sijasta toisen asiakkaan tai asiakasryhmän etuja; harjoittaa samaa toimintaa sijoitusrahastoa varten kuin muuta asiakasta tai muita asiakkaita kuin sijoitusrahastoja varten; saa tai tulee saamaan joltakin muulta kuin sijoitusrahastolta sellaisen kannustimen rahana, tavarana tai palveluna, joka liittyy sijoitusrahaston salkunhoitoon ja poikkeaa kyseisestä palvelusta tavallisesti perittävästä palkkiosta tai maksusta. requirements.text: Credit risk disclosures shall provide information about an entity's credit risk management practices and how they relate to the recognition and measurement of expected credit losses, including the methods, assumptions and information used to measure expected credit losses. Disclosures shall also provide quantitative and qualitative information that allows users of financial statements to evaluate the amounts in the financial statements arising from expected credit losses, including changes in the amount of expected credit losses and the reasons for those changes, and information about the entity's credit risk exposure, including significant credit risk concentrations.

An entity shall explain its credit risk management practices and how they relate to the recognition and measurement of expected credit losses, including how it determined whether credit risk has increased significantly since initial recognition (including low credit risk assessment and rebuttal of the 30-day past due presumption), its definitions of default, how instruments were grouped for collective measurement, how it determined credit-impaired assets, its write-off policy, and how modification requirements have been applied.

An entity shall explain the inputs, assumptions and estimation techniques used to apply the requirements in Section 5.5 of IFRS 9, including the basis of inputs and assumptions and estimation techniques used to measure expected credit losses, determine significant increase in credit risk, and determine if an asset is credit-impaired. The entity shall also disclose how forward-looking information has been incorporated into the determination of expected credit losses, including the use of macroeconomic information.

To explain the changes in the loss allowance and the reasons for those changes, an entity shall provide, by class of financial instrument, a reconciliation from the opening balance to the closing balance of the loss allowance, showing separately changes for loss allowance measured at 12-month expected credit losses, lifetime expected credit losses (for instruments with significant credit risk increase, credit-impaired assets, and certain receivables), and purchased or originated credit-impaired financial assets. In addition, an entity shall disclose the total amount of undiscounted expected credit losses at initial recognition on financial assets initially recognised during the reporting period.

Valvottavan on kirjattava odotettavissa oleva luottotappio IFRS 9.4.1.2:n, IFRS 9.4.1.2A:n mukaisista rahoitusvaroista, vuokrasaamisista, luottositoumuksista ja takaussopimuksista. Odotettavissa oleva luottotappio on merkittävä kirjanpitojärjestelmiin vähennyserätilille viipymättä. Valvottavan tulee seurata vähennyserätileillä kumuloituneita odotettavissa olevia luottotappio määriä.

Valvottavalla tulee olla sellaiset järjestelmät, että se voi saamiskohtaisesti selvittää seuraavat asiat: odotettavissa olevien luottotappioiden vaihe; saamisen maksamaton pääoma (bruttomäärä); saamisen bruttomäärän mukaan laskettu korkosaaminen; saamisesta aikaisempina tilikausina kirjattujen odotettavissa oleva luottotappioiden kokonaismäärä tai jos se kuuluu johonkin ryhmään vaiheessa 1 ja 2, kyseisestä ryhmästä aikaisempina tilikausina kirjattujen odotettavissa olevien luottotappioiden määrä; tilikauden aikana tehdyt odotettavissa olevien luottotappioiden lisäykset ja peruuttamiset tai jos se kuuluu johonkin ryhmään vaiheessa 1 ja 2, kyseisen ryhmän odotettavissa olevien luottotappioiden lisäykset ja peruuttamiset; tilikauden aikana lopullisina luottotappioina poistetut saamiset; saadut suoritukset lopullisina luottotappioina poistetuista saamisista. Vastaavasti kuin kohdassa (16) valvottavan järjestelmien tulee seurata myös luottositoumuksista ja takaussopimuksista kirjattavien odotettavissa olevien luottotappioiden vaihetta ja niistä aikaisempina tilikausina kirjattujen odotettavissa olevien luottotappioiden kokonaismäärää, odotettavissa olevien luottotappioiden lisäyksiä ja peruuttamisia.

IFRS 9.5.5.1). Luottolaitosten arvonalentumismenetelmissä on selkeästi dokumentoitava keskeisten luottoriskin arviointiin ja odotettavissa olevien luottotappioiden mittaamiseen liittyvien termien määritelmät. Valvottavan tulee dokumentoida: kriteerit, joiden perusteella arvioidaan luottoriskin merkittävä lisääntyminen (siirtyminen vaiheeseen 2); kriteerit, joiden perusteella arvioidaan, onko luoton tai saamisen arvo alentunut luottoriskin johdosta (siirtyminen vaiheeseen 3).

requirements.text: Credit institutions must comply with these guidelines in a manner appropriate to their size, internal organization, the nature, scope, and complexity of their activities and portfolios, and all other relevant facts and circumstances, including those of the group to which they belong.

Credit institutions must consider a wide range of information, including past events, current conditions, and forecasts of future economic conditions, when applying ECL accounting models. This information must be reasonable and supportable, based on relevant facts and sound judgment. Credit institutions must be able to demonstrate how this information was considered. Information should not be excluded simply because an event has a low likelihood or uncertain effect, and any exclusion of reasonable and supportable information requires a clearly documented, robust justification as such circumstances are exceptional. The information used must include an unbiased consideration of relevant factors and their impact on creditworthiness and cash shortfalls.

Credit institutions must adopt, document, and adhere to policies that include sound methodologies, procedures, and controls for assessing and measuring credit risk on all lending exposures. The measurement of allowances must build upon these methodologies, resulting in the appropriate and timely recognition of ECL according to the applicable accounting framework. The process should provide senior management with the relevant information for experienced judgments about credit risk and ECL estimation.

Credit institutions should, to the maximum extent possible, leverage and integrate common processes, systems, tools, and data used for granting credit, monitoring credit risk, and measuring allowances for both accounting and capital adequacy purposes. This integration should also apply to the use of common processes, systems, tools, and data for assessing credit risk, measuring ECL for accounting purposes, and determining expected losses for capital adequacy purposes to strengthen reliability, consistency, increase transparency, and incentivize sound credit risk practices.

Under the internal ratings based approach, where the total expected loss amount is less than total eligible provisions (measured gross of tax effects), banks may recognise the difference in Tier 2 capital up to a maximum of 0.6% of credit risk-weighted assets calculated under the internal ratings-based approach.

Banks using the internal ratings-based (IRB) approach for other asset classes must compare the amount of total eligible provisions, as defined in CRE35.4, with the total expected loss amount as calculated within the IRB approach and defined in CRE35.2.

The calculation of expected loss amounts shall be based on the same input figures of PD, LGD and the exposure value for each exposure as are used for the calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts in accordance with Article 151.

Institutions shall subtract the expected loss amounts calculated in accordance with Article 158 (5), (6) and (10) from the general and specific credit risk adjustments and additional value adjustments in accordance with Articles 34 and 110 and other own funds reductions related to these exposures.

overlaps.reason: This group of requirements outlines the comprehensive framework for calculating and accounting for Expected Credit Losses (ECL). The CELEX document provides the core IFRS 9 principles. The Finnish regulation (2016_02.m4.di.json) details the national implementation and system requirements. The EBA Guidelines (EBA-GL-2017-06) offer extensive prudential guidance on methodology and governance. Finally, the CRR and Basel Framework specify how these accounting provisions (ECL) interact with regulatory capital calculations (Expected Loss under IRB), creating a cohesive but multi-layered regulatory structure.

requirements.text: The granting of credit shall be based on sound and well-defined criteria. Credit decisions by a supervised entity shall be based on a credit analysis, which must give a sufficiently accurate picture of the borrower applying for credit, the borrower's creditworthiness and of the project to be financed. The assessment of creditworthiness must be made with respect to both new credits, renewed credits and changes of credit terms and conditions. Credit decisions must be primarily based on the customer's creditworthiness.

To analyse the financial status and creditworthiness, sufficient information must be obtained about the customer, and the accuracy of the information must be ascertained in an appropriate manner. The information and documents needed as background for the decision must be listed.

At a minimum, the following factors must be considered in the context of credit decisions: the borrower's previous repayment performance, current repayment capacity and estimate of future repayment capacity considering all of its assets and liabilities; the purpose of use of the credit and the source of funds for its repayment (continuity factors must be taken into account); the funding plan for the project and the proportion of the borrower's equity finance; collateral type, valuation, coverage and realisability; in case the credit is amortised on a very back-loaded repayment plan, the plan for paying the largest instalments; and how the credit decision is consistent with the credit strategy.

requirements.text: Credit risk policies and procedures should specify credit-granting criteria, taking into account the items referred to in Annex 1.
Credit risk policies and procedures should specify requirements for the creditworthiness assessment, including a sensitivity analysis, as referred to in Section 5.2.

Institutions and creditors should have sufficient, accurate and up-to-date information and data necessary to assess the borrower's creditworthiness and risk profile before concluding a loan agreement.

Institutions and creditors should, in line with the relevant consumer protection legislation, assess the borrower's ability and prospect to meet the obligations under the loan agreement, covering, in particular, an assessment of the borrower's source of repayment capacity, taking into account specificities of the loan, such as nature, maturity and interest rate.

Banks must perform due diligence to ensure that they have an adequate understanding, at origination and thereafter on a regular basis (at least annually), of the risk profile and characteristics of their counterparties.

Banks must take reasonable and adequate steps to assess the operating and financial performance levels and trends through internal credit analysis and/or other analytics outsourced to a third party, as appropriate for each counterparty.

The supervisor determines that banks have prudent policies and processes to identify, measure, evaluate, monitor, report and control or mitigate credit risk (including counterparty credit risk) on a timely basis.
The granting of credit must be based on sound and well-defined criteria.

Before concluding a credit agreement, the creditor shall assess the consumer's creditworthiness based on sufficient credit register information and other data on the consumer's income and financial/economic circumstances.

Before concluding a credit agreement, the creditor shall assess the consumer's creditworthiness based on necessary, sufficient, and proportionate information from a credit information register and other financial data, and the correctness of this information must be appropriately verified.

The Basel Framework provides the high-level international standard that supervisors must enforce, ensuring banks have prudent policies for assuming credit risk. Together, they form a multi-level system of principles and detailed procedures for credit granting.

requirements.text: The board of directors of a credit institution shall approve the strategies and procedures concerning the risks relating to the credit institution and its activity as well as regularly monitor them. All material risks, risk management guidelines and any changes thereto shall be reported to the board of directors.

The task of the risk supervisory function is to identify, measure and report the material risks of the credit institution to the board of directors. The supervisory function shall actively participate in the preparation of a risk strategy and in the making of all essential decisions concerning risk management as well as ensure that the board of directors is given a comprehensive view of the risks affecting the credit institution.

requirements.text: Competent authorities should review the governance and risk management framework underlying credit activities throughout the loan life cycle, assessing whether the institution has a sound, clearly formulated, and documented credit risk appetite, strategy, and limits approved by the management body. Senior management must properly implement and monitor this strategy, ensuring consistency with activities, clear procedures, and assigned responsibilities. The credit and counterparty risk strategy must reflect credit risk appetite and be consistent with the overall risk appetite, and be appropriate for the institution's business model, market environment, financial condition, funding capacity, and own funds adequacy. The strategy must cover credit-granting, collateral management, and NPE management, supporting risk-based decision-making across relevant aspects (exposure type, sector, location, currency, maturity, including concentration limits), and broadly cover all significant credit risk activities, taking into account cyclical economic aspects, including under stress.

requirements.text: The management body's responsibilities should include setting, approving and overseeing the implementation of the overall risk strategy, the institution's risk appetite and its risk management framework and measures to ensure that the management body devotes sufficient time to risk and risk management issues.

Institutions should establish a risk management function (RMF) covering the whole institution. There should be a central RMF, including a group RMF in the consolidating institution, to deliver an institution- and group-wide holistic view on all risks and to ensure that the risk strategy is complied with. Significant institutions may consider establishing dedicated RMFs for each material business line. The RMF should be a central organisational feature of the institution, structured so that it can implement risk policies and control the risk management framework.

The RMF should play a key role in ensuring that the institution has effective risk management processes in place and should be actively involved in all material risk management decisions and at an early stage in elaborating the institution's risk strategy and in ensuring that the institution has effective risk management processes in place.

requirements.text: All decisions concerning the granting of credit and all changes of terms and conditions of credit must be made on an arm's-length basis. All credit or comparable finance to related individuals, companies or foundations must be extended on the same terms and conditions as to non-related borrowers. Senior management shall adopt general terms and conditions for credit to closely associated persons and all decisions concerning credit to closely associated persons. Supervised entities must ensure that credit is not extended to closely associated persons at terms and conditions that could jeopardise the supervised entity's financial status or otherwise the confidence in its operations.

A credit institution shall report to the Financial Supervisory Authority any transactions where one of the parties is the credit institution and the other party is an undertaking which belongs to the same group as the credit institution, or which is a participating undertaking referred to in the Accounting Act of the credit institution or of an undertaking belonging to the same group.
The following intra-group transactions must be reported, with a view to the thresholds under section 4.2, paragraph 1: capital loans, credits, guarantees and issued collateral.

requirements.text: When deciding on a loan or other transaction with a member of the management body or their related parties, before taking a decision, institutions should assess the risk to which the institution might be exposed due to the transaction.

Institutions' measures to manage or where appropriate mitigate conflicts of interest should be documented and include, inter alia: establishing adequate procedures for transactions with related parties, e.g. requiring transactions to be conducted at arm's length.
The RMF should ensure that transactions with related parties are reviewed and that the risks they pose for the institution are identified and adequately assessed.

Decisions concerning loans, other comparable financing, or investments granted to or made in a natural person, organization, or foundation belonging to a credit institution's close circle, as well as the general terms applicable to such lending and investment, must be approved by the Board of Directors of the credit institution. The provisions regarding loan granting shall correspondingly apply to granting a guarantee or placing other collateral for a loan granted by another party.

requirements.text: Supervised entities must ensure that they use reliable methods in the appraisal of the current value of eligible collateral, which take internationally acknowledged appraisal standards into account, and that the appraiser is qualified and independent enough of the credit process. If the collateral appraised includes other than ordinary residential properties, such as commercial properties, production spaces etc or other objects that are difficult to appraise, the supervised entity shall ensure that the appraiser has sufficient expertise and that the appraisal is conducted with particular care.

Supervised entities must have documented procedures and guidelines for: accepting different types of collateral; regularly monitoring and assessing collateral values; collateral valuation (hair-cut); and ensuring that collateral is binding, adequate and realisable. Supervised entities shall establish acceptable types of collateral as well as collateral valuation percentages for each type of acceptable collateral. The valuation percentages shall be consistent with a prudential maximum limit for the relevant types of collateral. Collateral value must always be based on a case-specific assessment, and special attention should be paid on collateral whose fair value cannot be considered stable. The valuer of collateral must be competent and adequately independent of the granting of credit.

requirements.text: [CREDIT_RISK] Credit institutions shall monitor the value of immovable property collateral frequently, at least as specified in Article 208(3) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013. Valuations of all secured exposures for prudential purposes must be updated according to Article 208(3) and Article 210(c) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013. requirements.text: At the point of origination, institutions should ensure that the value of all immovable property collateral for loans to consumers and micro, small, medium-sized and large enterprises is assessed by an internal or external valuer using full visit with internal and external assessment of the property.

Institutions should take reasonable steps, e.g. via contractual terms, to ensure that valuers who are going to carry out the actual appraisal of a given property and their first-degree relatives are not guided or influenced by the borrower's creditworthiness.

The creditor must ensure that the appraiser conducting valuations of residential property used as security is sufficiently independent from the credit granting process and uses reliable valuation procedures based on standards.

A mortgage-backed loan is only eligible as collateral if, when granting the credit, the fair value of the collateral asset has been determined in compliance with the provisions of the EU Capital Requirements Regulation and chapter 9, section 10 of the Act on Credit Institutions as well as provisions on credit risk management issued by the Financial Supervisory Authority by virtue of chapter 9, section 24 of the Act on Credit Institutions.

The various guidelines and regulations build on this by specifying frequencies for revaluation (e.g., annually for NPEs, quarterly monitoring for covered bonds) and acceptable valuation methodologies.

documents.filename: Final Report on Guidelines on recovery plan indicators.di.json

requirements.text: The thresholds for indicators based on regulatory capital requirements should be calibrated by the institution at adequate levels to ensure a sufficient distance from a breach of the applicable capital requirements, including minimum own funds requirements (Article 92 of Regulation (EU) 575/2013) and additional own funds requirements (Article 104(1)(a) of Directive 2013/36/EU). Regulatory capital indicators should generally be set at a level higher than those that will allow supervisory intervention. Generally, capital indicators should be calibrated above the combined capital buffer requirement. Where an institution calibrates its capital indicators within the buffers, it must clearly demonstrate in its recovery plan that its recovery options can be implemented in a situation where the buffers have been totally or partially used.
A capital conservation buffer of 2.5%, comprised of Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1), is established above the regulatory minimum capital requirement.
Capital distribution constraints will be imposed on a bank when capital levels fall within the capital conservation buffer range.
The fixed capital add-on is 2.5 per cent of the credit institution's total risk exposure. The provisions regarding this fixed capital add-on also apply to the consolidated capital add-on.

A credit institution that fails to complete the capital add-on referred to in this Chapter must accrue its own funds by limiting the distribution of profits as provided for in subsection 2 (in derogation from Chapter 11, section 8). The minimum accrual amount is calculated by multiplying the amount of distributable funds by a multiplier determined by how far below the capital add-on the institution falls (pro rata share).

overlaps.reason: This group of requirements details the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCB) and the associated constraints on capital distributions. The Basel Framework establishes the international standard, defining the 2.5% buffer level and the tiered payout restrictions. The Finnish Act on Credit Institutions (610_2014) transposes these rules into national law. The EBA Guidelines on recovery plan indicators complement this by requiring recovery triggers to be set at a level that provides an early warning before these mandatory buffer constraints are breached.

requirements.text: Institutions should not recognise the effects of CRM techniques more than once; this implies that, in allocating the FCP between the part of the exposure that is also covered by UFCP and the part of the exposure that is not, double counting of the FCP should not be allowed. Institutions should not recognise the effects of the same credit risk mitigation twice; for example, in allocating the funded credit protection between the part of the exposure covered by the unfunded credit protection and the part of the exposure that is not covered by the unfunded credit protection, double recognition of the funded credit protection should not be allowed.
No supervisory recognition of credit risk mitigation will be granted on exposures for which the risk weight already reflects that CRM.

Where the risk-weighted exposure amount already takes account of credit protection under Chapter 2 or Chapter 3, as applicable, institutions shall not take into account that credit protection in the calculations under this Chapter.

overlaps.reason: These requirements from the Basel Framework, CRR, and EBA Guidelines all articulate the same fundamental principle for credit risk mitigation (CRM): the risk-mitigating effects of a technique (such as collateral or a guarantee) must not be recognized more than once. This prohibition on 'double counting' ensures that capital relief is not overstated, for example, by reflecting the same collateral both in a lower LGD estimate and again through a separate capital calculation adjustment.

requirements.text: The underlying assets (the cover pool) of covered bonds shall meet the requirements set out in CRE20.37 and shall include any of the following: (1) claims on, or guaranteed by, sovereigns, their central banks, public sector entities or multilateral development banks; (2) claims secured by residential real estate that meet the criteria set out in CRE20.71 and with a loan-to-value ratio of 80% or lower; (3) claims secured by commercial real estate that meets the criteria set out in CRE20.71 and with a loan-to-value ratio of 60% or lower; or (4) claims on, or guaranteed by, banks that qualify for a 30% or lower risk weight. For regulatory residential real estate exposures that are not materially dependent on cash flow generated by the property, the risk weight to be assigned to the total exposure amount will be determined based on the exposure's LTV ratio in Table 11 below.

For regulatory residential real estate exposures that are materially dependent on cash flows generated by the property, the risk weight to be assigned to the total exposure amount will be determined based on the exposure's LTV ratio in Table 12 below.

The loan amount granted for the purchase of a first home can be at maximum 95 per cent of the current value of the collateral securities at the time of granting. For other loans, the maximum loan amount is 90 per cent of the current value of the collateral securities.

Institutions may derogate from point (b) of paragraph 2 for exposures secured by residential property within a Member State if the competent authority has published evidence of a well-developed and long-established residential property market where loss rates do not exceed: (a) losses from loans collateralised by residential property up to 80 % of market value or 80 % of mortgage-lending-value (unless per Article 124(2)) do not exceed 0,3 % of outstanding loans annually; (b) overall losses from loans collateralised by residential property do not exceed 0,5 % of outstanding loans annually.

requirements.text: Any assertion that the more-than-30-days-past-due presumption is rebutted based on no significant increase in credit risk must be accompanied by a thorough analysis demonstrating that 30 days past due is not correlated with a significant increase in credit risk. This analysis must consider current and reasonable and supportable forward-looking information. Credit institutions should only use the 30-days-past-due rebuttable presumption if they have demonstrated that forward-looking information had no substantive relationship with the credit risk driver or if such information is unavailable without undue cost or effort. If past-due information is the best criterion for moving to lifetime ECL, particular attention must be paid to 12-month ECL measurement to ensure appropriate capture according to IFRS 9 measurement objectives.
A default is considered to have occurred when the obligor is past due more than 90 days on any material credit obligation to the banking group.

A default shall be considered to have occurred with regard to a particular obligor when either or both of the following have taken place: (a) the institution considers that the obligor is unlikely to pay its credit obligations to the institution, the parent undertaking or any of its subsidiaries in full, without recourse by the institution to actions such as realising security; (b) the obligor is past due more than 90 days on any material credit obligation to the institution, the parent undertaking or any of its subsidiaries.

overlaps.reason: These requirements distinguish between two key past-due thresholds in the credit risk lifecycle. In contrast, the 90-day past due threshold is consistently defined across the Basel Framework and CRR as a primary trigger for an exposure being classified as defaulted for regulatory capital purposes. The rules are complementary, marking different stages of credit deterioration.

requirements.text: The FIN-FSA recommends that supervised entities' risk management also take into account that the supervised entity's counterparty risk must be monitored if decision-making related to customer relationships is outsourced.

requirements.text: Under the foundation approach, senior claims on sovereigns, banks, securities firms and other financial institutions (including insurance companies and any financial institutions in the corporate asset class) that are not secured by recognised collateral will be assigned a 45% LGD.

requirements.text: Under the other approaches [to collateralised transactions], when there is a maturity mismatch the credit protection arrangement may only be recognised if the original maturity of the arrangement is greater than or equal to one year, and its residual maturity is greater than or equal to three months.

The approach for collateralised portions shall not be used if there is a maturity mismatch between the exposure and the protection. Institutions may use both the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Method and the collateral treatment approach only if permitted to use both the Simple and Comprehensive Methods for Article 92 purposes.

requirements.text: The Board of the supervised entity is responsible for adequate information security within the entity. requirements.text: Institutions shall establish internal requirements that ensure that the collateral agreement (FCP) is legally effective and enforceable, ensuring the power of the creditor to enforce the realisation of the collateral.

Institutions should obtain a legal opinion confirming the legal effectiveness and enforceability of the FCP in all relevant jurisdictions. This opinion should be provided in a written form by a legal counsel who is independent from the credit decision process and is not responsible for originating or renewing the exposures under consideration. Legal opinions should be obtained at least for each type of collateral arrangement rather than for each specific collateral arrangement. Where a single legal opinion is issued for multiple collateral arrangements, that legal opinion must relate to the same applicable law and must be in relation to the same type of obligor. Any substantive variation to the terms of the collateral arrangement that could affect the legal effectiveness and enforceability of the specific collateral arrangement should trigger the need for an additional legal opinion.
Institutions should establish internal requirements that ensure that the UFCP arrangement is legally effective and enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions.

Institutions should obtain a legal opinion confirming the legal effectiveness and enforceability of the UFCP in all relevant jurisdictions, as required in Article 183(1)(c) of the CRR. This legal opinion should be provided in written form by a legal counsel who is independent from the credit decision processes responsible for originating or renewing the exposures under consideration. Legal opinions should be obtained for each type of UFCP contract rather than for each specific UFCP contract (noting that a single legal opinion can be obtained for multiple UFCP contracts, if they are subject to the same applicable law). Institutions should obtain an additional legal opinion relating to any substantive variation to the terms of the contract that could affect the legal effectiveness and enforceability of the arrangement of the specific unfunded credit protection.

Institutions should ensure that the collateral arrangement under which the collateral is provided is legally effective and enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions, giving the institution the right to liquidate or repossess the collateral in a reasonable timeframe, including in the event of the default, bankruptcy or insolvency of the obligor and, where applicable, of the custodian holding the collateral.

Institutions should ensure that they obtain the legal opinion or opinions confirming that the collateral arrangement under which the other physical collateral is provided is legally effective and enforceable at least in the jurisdiction whose law governs the collateral arrangement and at least in the jurisdiction where it is most likely that the realisation of the collateral would be carried out should this be necessary. Institutions should obtain a legal opinion confirming the legal effectiveness and enforceability of the collateral arrangement in all relevant jurisdictions for the purposes of paragraph 17. Legal opinions for FCP should be carried out at least for each type of collateral arrangement and provided in a written form by a legal counsel. Institutions may rely on a single legal opinion in relation to multiple collateral arrangements where it relates to the same applicable law, or cover several jurisdictions, particularly where international regulations provide a robust international framework enforcing creditors' rights over their collateral. Institutions should obtain additional legal opinion relating to any substantive variation to the terms of the collateral arrangement that could affect the legal effectiveness and enforceability of the specific collateral arrangement.

Institutions should obtain a legal opinion confirming that the unfunded credit protection arrangement is legally effective and enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions. The legal opinion for UFCP should be carried out at least for each type of unfunded credit protection and provided in written form by a legal counsel. Institutions may rely on a single legal opinion to support multiple unfunded credit protection arrangements where it relates to the same applicable law.

requirements.text: For movable property, credit institutions shall conduct a sufficient legal review confirming the enforceability of the collateral, including an assessment of the legal right to enforce and liquidate the collateral in the event of default, within a reasonable timeframe.

To obtain capital relief for any use of CRM techniques, all documentation for collateralised transactions, on-balance sheet netting agreements, guarantees, and credit derivatives must be binding on all parties and legally enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions. Banks must have conducted sufficient legal review to verify enforceability, have a well-founded legal basis for this conclusion, and undertake further review as necessary to ensure continuing enforceability.

The legal mechanism for pledging or transferring collateral must ensure the bank can liquidate or take possession of it in a timely manner upon counterparty default, insolvency, bankruptcy, or other defined credit events. Banks must take all necessary steps to fulfill local requirements for maintaining an enforceable security interest (e.g., registration) or exercising set-off rights.

The effects of bilateral netting agreements covering SFTs may be recognized on a counterparty-by-counterparty basis if they are legally enforceable in each relevant jurisdiction upon an event of default, regardless of counterparty insolvency or bankruptcy. Netting agreements must provide the non-defaulting party the right to terminate/close out transactions timely upon default (including insolvency), net gains/losses (including collateral value) to a single net amount owed, allow prompt liquidation/set-off of collateral, and be legally enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions upon default, irrespective of insolvency.

For collateral recognition in IRB, any claim on collateral must be legally enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions, properly filed timely, reflect a perfected lien (all legal requirements fulfilled), and the legal mechanism must ensure the bank can realize the collateral's value within a reasonable timeframe with clear rights over proceeds. Banks must take all steps necessary to fulfill local requirements for enforcing security interests (e.g., registration). A framework allowing the potential lender a perfected first priority claim over the collateral should exist. All documentation must be binding and legally enforceable, verified by sufficient legal review. In case of obligor distress/default, the bank should have legal authority to sell/assign receivables without obligor consent. Compliance with loan covenants, environmental restrictions, and other legal requirements should be reviewed regularly. Only first liens or charges are permissible, except for specified prior claims, ensuring the bank has priority over all other lenders to realized proceeds. General Security Agreements (floating charges) can provide a registered claim over assets.

Banks applying netting must satisfy their national supervisor via written and reasoned legal reviews that courts/authorities would find the net exposure enforceable under: (a) the law of the counterparty's chartering jurisdiction (and branch jurisdiction if applicable); (b) the law governing individual transactions; and (c) the law governing any contract necessary to effect netting. Banks must have procedures to keep the legal characteristics of netting arrangements under review for changes in relevant law. The national supervisor, after consulting others if necessary, must be satisfied that netting is enforceable under the laws of each relevant jurisdiction. The process for recognizing netting arrangements must require signoff by legal staff verifying enforceability and input by an independent unit.

For margined counterparties, all documentation used in collateralised transactions must be binding on all parties and legally enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions. Banks must have conducted sufficient legal review to verify this and have a well-founded legal basis, undertaking further review as necessary for continuing enforceability.

A guarantee shall be evidenced in writing, non-cancellable on the part of the guarantor, in force until the obligation is satisfied in full (to the extent of the amount and tenor of the guarantee) and legally enforceable against the guarantor in a jurisdiction where the guarantor has assets to attach and enforce a judgement. Conditional guarantees prescribing conditions under which the guarantor may not be obliged to perform may be recognised subject to permission of the competent authorities.

The technique used to provide the credit protection together with the actions and steps taken and procedures and policies implemented by the lending institution shall be such as to result in credit protection arrangements which are legally effective and enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions. The lending institution shall provide, upon request of the competent authority, the most recent version of the independent, written and reasoned legal opinion or opinions that it used to establish whether its credit protection arrangement or arrangements meet the condition laid down in the first subparagraph.

Master netting agreements covering repurchase transactions, securities or commodities lending or borrowing transactions or other capital market driven transactions shall qualify as an eligible form of credit risk mitigation where the collateral provided under those agreements meets all the requirements laid down in Article 207(2) to (4) and where all the following conditions are met: (a) they are legally effective and enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions, including in the event of the bankruptcy or insolvency of the counterparty; (b) they give the non-defaulting party the right to terminate and close-out in a timely manner all transactions under the agreement upon the event of default, including in the event of the bankruptcy or insolvency of the counterparty; (c) they provide for the netting of gains and losses on transactions closed out under an agreement so that a single net amount is owed by one party to the other.

Institutions shall fulfil any contractual and statutory requirements in respect of, and take all steps necessary to ensure, the enforceability of the collateral arrangements under the law applicable to their interest in the collateral. Institutions shall have conducted sufficient legal review confirming the enforceability of the collateral arrangements in all relevant jurisdictions. The protection agreement and the legal process underpinning it enable the institution to realise the value of the protection within a reasonable timeframe [for immovable property collateral]. Institutions shall take all steps necessary to fulfil local requirements in respect of the enforceability of security interest [for receivables collateral]. Lending institutions shall have a first priority claim over the collateral although such claims may still be subject to the claims of preferential creditors provided for in legislative provisions [for receivables collateral]. Institutions shall have conducted sufficient legal review confirming the enforceability of the collateral arrangements in all relevant jurisdictions [for receivables collateral]. Institutions shall have in place procedures that ensure that any legal conditions required for declaring the default of a borrower and timely collection of collateral are observed [for receivables collateral]. In the event of a borrower's financial distress or default, institutions shall have legal authority to sell or assign the receivables to other parties without consent of the receivables obligors [for receivables collateral]. They shall also review, on a regular basis, compliance with loan covenants, environmental restrictions, and other legal requirements [for receivables collateral].

Physical collateral other than immovable property collateral shall qualify as eligible collateral under the IRB Approach where all the following conditions are met: (a) the collateral arrangement under which the physical collateral is provided to an institution shall be legally effective and enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions and shall enable that institution to realise the value of the collateral within a reasonable timeframe; (b) with the sole exception of permissible first priority claims referred to in Article 209(2)(b), only first liens on, or charges over, collateral shall qualify as eligible collateral and an institution shall have priority over all other lenders to the realised proceeds of the collateral; (c) institutions shall monitor the value of the collateral on a frequent basis and at least once every year.

Cash on deposit with, or cash assimilated instruments held by, a third party institution shall be eligible for the treatment set out in Article 232(1), where all the following conditions are met: (a) the borrower's claim against the third party institution is openly pledged or assigned to the lending institution and such pledge or assignment is legally effective and enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions and is unconditional and irrevocable; (b) the third party institution is notified of the pledge or assignment; (c) as a result of the notification, the third party institution is able to make payments solely to the lending institution or to other parties only with the lending institution's prior consent.

The pledge or assignment [of life insurance policy] is legally effective and enforceable in all jurisdictions which are relevant at the time of the conclusion of the credit agreement. The company providing the life insurance is subject to Directive 2009/138/EC or is subject to supervision by a competent authority of a third country which applies supervisory and regulatory arrangements at least equivalent to those applied in the Union.

Credit protection deriving from a guarantee or credit derivative shall qualify as eligible unfunded credit protection where all the following conditions are met: (a) the credit protection is direct; (b) the extent of the credit protection is clearly defined and incontrovertible; (c) the credit protection contract does not contain any clause, the fulfilment of which is outside the direct control of the lender, that would allow unilateral cancellation, increased effective cost due to credit deterioration, prevention of timely payout, or reduction of maturity by the protection provider; (d) the credit protection contract is legally effective and enforceable in all jurisdictions which are relevant at the time of the conclusion of the credit agreement. An institution shall fulfil any contractual and statutory requirements in respect of, and take all steps necessary to ensure, the enforceability of its unfunded credit protection under the law applicable to its interest in the credit protection. An institution shall have conducted sufficient legal review confirming the enforceability of the unfunded credit protection in all relevant jurisdictions. The guarantee is an explicitly documented obligation assumed by the guarantor. Where the protection purchaser's right and ability to transfer the underlying obligation to the protection provider is required for settlement, the terms of the underlying obligation provide that any required consent to such transfer shall not be unreasonably withheld. Where the payout structure of the credit protection provides for physical settlement, there is legal certainty with respect to the deliverability of a loan, bond, or contingent liability. The terms and conditions of credit protection arrangements are legally confirmed in writing by both the protection provider and the institution.

For securitisation, the securitised exposures must be put beyond the reach of the originator institution and its creditors, including in bankruptcy and receivership, and the securitisation documentation must reflect the economic substance of the transaction. The securitised exposures being put beyond the reach of the originator must be supported by the opinion of qualified legal counsel. An opinion is obtained from qualified legal counsel confirming the enforceability of the credit protection in all relevant jurisdictions [for synthetic securitisation].

requirements.text: [MARKET_RISK] Competent authorities should assess whether the institution has a sound, clearly formulated and documented market risk strategy, approved by its management body, which properly reflects the institution's appetite for market risk, is consistent with the overall risk appetite, and is appropriate given the institution's business model, market environment, financial condition, funding capacity, capital adequacy, and role in the financial system. This strategy must establish guidance for managing different instruments/portfolios subject to market risk and support risk-based decision-making, broadly covering all significant market risk activities, and taking into account the cyclical aspects of the economy.

The management body must ensure clear guidance regarding the risk appetite for IRRBB in respect of the institution's business strategies. The management body or its delegates are responsible for setting: i. appropriate limits on IRRBB, including exception procedures; ii. systems and standards for measuring IRRBB, valuing positions, and assessing performance (including updating shocks, parameters, and scenarios); iii. a comprehensive IRRBB reporting and review process; and iv. effective internal controls and management information systems (MISs). The level of and changes in IRRBB exposure must be reported regularly (at least quarterly) to the management body.

Laws, regulations or the supervisor require banks to have appropriate market risk management processes that provide a comprehensive bank-wide view of market risk exposure. Banks shall have comprehensive risk measurement systems for the accurate and timely identification, aggregation, monitoring and reporting of market risk exposures to the board and senior management. Banks shall establish appropriate market risk limits, consistent with risk appetite, profile, capital strength, and management's ability to manage market risk, which must be understood by and regularly communicated to relevant staff. Banks shall establish exception tracking and reporting processes ensuring prompt action at the appropriate level of senior management or board. Banks shall establish sound policies and processes for the allocation of exposures to the trading book. Banks are required to ensure their marked-to-market positions are revalued frequently. Banks are required to ensure all transactions are captured on a timely basis, that the valuation process uses consistent and prudent practices and reliable market data verified by a function independent of the risk-taking units (or internal/industry-accepted models if no market prices exist). Banks are required to establish and maintain policies and processes for considering valuation adjustments for positions that cannot be prudently valued (including concentrated, less liquid, and stale positions). Banks shall hold appropriate levels of capital against unexpected losses and make appropriate valuation adjustments for uncertainties in determining fair value.

The Board of Directors shall approve the risk strategy and other strategic objectives of the credit institution and ensure that their compliance is reliably monitored. The Board of Directors of a credit institution shall approve the strategies and procedures concerning the risks relating to the credit institution and its activity as well as regularly monitor them. All material risks, risk management guidelines and any changes thereto shall be reported to the Board of Directors. The Board of Directors of the credit institution shall spend adequate time in handling matters concerning the risks of the credit institution as well as ensure that the credit institution has sufficient powers to take care of the tasks concerning risk management referred to in this Act and the Capital Requirements Regulation.
